body: Good catch @quirinkrabi! It looks like this is caused by numpy pinned to 1.21. I've found explanations here and there https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/47691 https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/48918 https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/48935. @MMathisLab, I think we should unpin numpy and see what we can do with numba if tests fail on Ubuntu + py3.7?

I can confirm that unpinning `numpy` in `setup.py` installs `tensorflow=2.6` and `testscript.py` completes on windows.

issue.title: Unpin numpy

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Unpin numpy in order for tensorflow >= 2.2 to function.

Fixes #1486 #1487

body:
Dear jeylau and others,

thank you, I am glad the issue can be fixed easily it seems. Can I ask, as I still do not understand very well how github works: After the pull request #1488 has been issued, when will the fix be included in the master installation? I.e. next time I do "pip install --upgrade deeplabcut" to upgrade, it will then be included?

Thanks and best wishes,
Quirin

Hello @quirinkrabi, 

To answer your question:
No, it wont be included right away. The update of the "deeplabcut"-package using pip is using the pypi-repository as a source, where only the version you installed is available right now, as this package has to be updated as well. 
This being said, you can unpin numpy in the package you already installed on your own. 
If you go to the `deeplabcut-2.2.0.1.dist-info`-Folder, which lays somewhere like this:
`C:\Anaconda\envs\DEEPLABCUT\Lib\site-packages\deeplabcut-2.2.0.1.dist-info`
you can the open the `METADATA`-file in a texteditor and remove the required version behind `numpy`.
If you then do `pip install --upgrade deeplabcut` it should install the right version of Tensorflow along with the right dependencies for it.
 
I hope that works for you. 

P.S. You might encounter the wx.Locale - Issue with matplotlib, as you are working on a Windows-machine. If you do: 
Add this line `locale = wx.Locale(wx.LANGUAGE_ENGLISH)` to the functions "_load_bitmap(filename)" and "_set_frame_icon(frame)" in the `C:\Anaconda\envs\DEEPLABCUT\Lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx`-File.
